text:
CHRISTINE LIU: I've been wanting
to do a video on imposter
syndrome since day one.

And it's because every time I
talk about it with other people

I work with, a lot
of times, women,

it's just like we
all feel this way.
Am I in the right place?
They picked me, but why?
They must have made a mistake.
I shouldn't be here.

Then I get upset with
myself because I'm like,
why am I feeling this way?
I should be confident.

I should be grateful
for this opportunity.
But I don't.
So what is wrong with me?

I just want to figure out, W-T-F
is up with imposter syndrome?

Why does it affect so many
smart, talented people?

And how do I deal
with these feelings?

So I thought I knew what
imposter syndrome was, but it

turns out, I didn't even
have the whole story.

And I'm going to show you what
I learned, so stick around.
It's going to be a game-changer.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JODI-ANN BUREY:
Imposter syndrome

has such a hold on
our cultural narrative

and has become the
predominant way

that we talk about women's
experiences typically
in white collar workplaces.

CHRISTINE LIU: That's
Jodi-Ann Burey.

She's a writer and
a speaker who works

at the intersections of race,
culture, and health equity.

She's the co-author
of the HBR article,

"Stop Telling Women They
Have Imposter Syndrome,"
with Ruchika Tulshyan.

Can you go into a little bit
about where this term actually
came from?

JODI-ANN BUREY: It was first
termed imposter phenomenon,

which I found probably the most
interesting of all of this,

in 1978 by Pauline
Clance and Suzanne Imes,

the two psychologists who were
first looking at a small sample

of predominantly white
high-income, quote unquote,
"high-achieving"--
put this in heavy quotations--

women in their
professional settings.

CHRISTINE LIU: So in this
study, published in 1978,

it says, "despite outstanding
academic and professional

accomplishments, women who
experience the imposter

phenomenon persist in believing
that they are really not bright

and have fooled anyone
who thinks otherwise."
Sound familiar?

JODI-ANN BUREY: Even though
it was first coined and termed

in 1978, our cultural
narrative and understanding

of imposter syndrome hasn't
really changed since then.

It just never really
resonated with me.

And so that led me on
this path of looking

at the original study,
formulating my own ideas

about it, and trying
to give language
to why it irritated me so much.

CHRISTINE LIU: Jodi-Ann
argues that imposter syndrome
is a distraction.

It's a false narrative
that people in power

use to draw attention away
from systemic problems

in the workplace, like lack of
opportunity, lack of fair pay,
lack of diversity.
The list goes on.

JODI-ANN BUREY: I think the
reason why imposter syndrome

still has such a hold on
our cultural narrative

is that there is enough
in it that's true.

You're in these environments
where those messages

take something that
is probably true

for everyone, that
self-doubt, that uncertainty,

and magnifies it,
where of course, it

would be difficult to
internalize your success

or to feel successful
when you're

feeling this constant barrage
of these chronic messages that

are just laced with
bias and discrimination.

The schools that you
went to weren't enough.
You aren't smart enough.

You aren't doing
the right thing.

Hey, you're the only person
like you in this room.
So yeah, you don't belong here.

CHRISTINE LIU: Let's all take
a step back, look further

upstream, and ask the
larger question, who and why
are people feeling this way?

JODI-ANN BUREY: When you belong
to a group that has either

been historically exploited
or abused in the workforce,

or you've been historically
excluded from the workforce,

it puts you in this
situation where you can still

feel that friction of that
historical exploitation, abuse,
or exclusion.

Even the mere fact that
our cultural narrative

had morphed imposter
phenomenon to imposter syndrome

illuminates this
inclination to provide

some faux medical
diagnosis for women

to explain away the chronic
discrimination that we've
experienced.

Imposter syndrome I
see as a safe for work

terminology versus
racism or sexism

and some of these
other systemic biases

that can perpetuate and
amplify these feelings that we
call imposter syndrome.

CHRISTINE LIU: Let's say
you're nervous because you
got a new job.
That's real.

Or you're scared
that your ideas might
be shot down in a meeting.
Those feelings are real too.
But are you an imposter?
Are you abnormal?
Do you have a condition?
No.

Jodi-Ann suggests thinking
of imposter syndrome

as a proxy term for something
else that might be going on.

JODI-ANN BUREY: For me,
first, I'm like, OK.

What type of imposter
syndrome is this?

This could be the
imposter syndrome

that's the proxy for me
just feeling uncertain

when I'm learning something or
I'm encountering something new,

and especially when the
stakes are really high.

I don't know anyone who wouldn't
feel some type of self-doubt

or uncertainty when
they're stepping

into a new role, a new industry,
a new job, a new department,
just a new project.

There is going to be something
that you're just like,
I don't know.
I don't know if I can do this.
Learning is so uncomfortable.

The last time I learned
something was snowboarding,
and it was very painful.

CHRISTINE LIU:
Oftentimes, the advice

you hear about impostor
syndrome sounds like--

JODI-ANN BUREY:
You're complaining.
Just be more confident.

Do a superhero pose
in the bathroom.
Just feel better about yourself.

That feels like the
easier thing to address.

But we don't look at the
fact that for a lot of women,

disproportionately
women of color,

it's the confidence that got you
in trouble in the first place.

CHRISTINE LIU: The
worst part of this

is that imposter syndrome puts
the pressure on the individual

to make changes
instead of the company
to perform and be better.
It becomes a really gross cycle.

JODI-ANN BUREY: Here's
a couple hundred bucks.
Go to your lady conference.

Go learn how to overcome
imposter syndrome.

But when you come
back to the office,
I'm still going to underpay you.

Still going to
interrupt you every time
you try to say something.

It positions companies to be
able to say, we want to change.
We want to be inclusive.

But then you never
have to change.

You never have to lean
more towards more inclusive

practices because you've
amplified a narrative where

you don't actually
have a direct role.

CHRISTINE LIU: When I realized
imposter syndrome isn't

something you must
conquer within oneself,

but is actually a
convenient shortcut

that glosses over what's
actually happening,
it changed the game for me.
It seriously blew my mind.

If you're feeling like you
have imposter syndrome,

Jodi-Ann has a
checklist of questions

you should ask yourself
so you can really

get to the bottom
of what's going on.

It's really helpful to have a
clear mind when you do this,
so create some space for that.
All right.
I'm going to try this.

So let's go with
these questions.

What is making me feel
like an imposter right now?

Well, I'll start
with an example.

I remember when I
felt like an imposter

when I was invited to be a small
hosting role, a huge conference

featuring some of the
most household name CEOs.

And I'm just like,
I'm not worthy.

Everybody else is way more
famous and interesting and
important.

So why am I invited
to the party?
When else have I felt this way?

I think any time that I am
in the presence of people

that I admire, or I feel
like they're just so worldly,

and who am I to share
that space with them?
I don't know.
This is honest.

Is there a trend or pattern
that makes me feel like this?

I think this goes into if
I am invited to something

or I get accepted to something,
and I'm just like, oh.

I'm looking around, and everyone
just seems a lot more with it.

And so I think it's
just comparison of me

or what I think I bring and what
I think everyone else brings,
and that's the gap.
Let's see.

How does it compare
to this time?
I don't know.
You know what?

I think it would be really weird
if I was one of the main guests
or anything like that.
That would have been weird.

But I think my
role in that event,

given my time here and
my contributions here,

does, upon reflection, seem
commensurate with the role
that I was given.

Reflect on your story, and it's
going to tell you something.

It might tell you that the
feelings you're feeling

are because you're
in something new.
You're learning.

That's super exciting, and
those feelings are normal.

It might also tell you that the
particular environment you're

working in is not
supporting you in the way
that you need it to be.

Let's say I have a
friend who comes to me

and they're having
a really tough time.
They're like, ugh.
Work is challenging.
I don't know what's going on.

I think this is just another
imposter syndrome flaring up.

What's your advice for sharing
all this goodness and mindset
and change to my friend?

JODI-ANN BUREY:
So first, you want

to acknowledge their
feelings and honor

the fact that they're coming
and sharing this with you.

And so what you don't want
to start with is saying,

you don't have
imposter syndrome.
Imposter syndrome is BS.
No.

You're going to say, I'm
really sorry that you're
going through that.
Acknowledge them first.

CHRISTINE LIU: Syndrome is
fake, but the feelings are real.

If it makes sense,
you can walk them

through some of those questions
from the checklist earlier

and try to pinpoint what is
triggering those feelings
of imposter syndrome.

Now that we've learned that
imposter syndrome is actually

systemic and not really
on the individual,
what can we do to address it?

No matter where you
sit in an organization,
you can be part of the solution.

One idea is to ask your company
for greater transparency on pay

and promotion rates across
demographics-- race, age,

gender, child status,
ability status, et cetera.

And address and
correct any bias.

Jodi-Ann also
suggests advocating

for equitable distributions of
resources to support your work.

JODI-ANN BUREY:
Oftentimes, you might

be asked to lead a task with
no money, no help, little time.

And so that can get
you into a cycle of oh,

maybe I'm not good enough
or smart enough for this

when maybe you're not
adequately supported

to execute on the
task because you
don't have the right resources.

CHRISTINE LIU: Keeping your
managers accountable is major,

asking for support, asking
for quality feedback,

and asking to not
be micromanaged.

You can also ask your
company about culture surveys

or feedback tools that
promote inclusive policies

and practices that
benefit everyone.

JODI-ANN BUREY:
It might not feel

as easy or as fast to
look at it structurally.

That's really the
only way that we

can ensure that we're
not still talking

about imposter syndrome in the
same way 50 years from now.

CHRISTINE LIU: Now is our
chance to rewrite the narrative.

Let's stop blaming
individuals and start holding
the larger systems accountable.
